content.title: Solana x402 Spotlights: Top Gainers, Most Traded, and Trending Tokens
content.description: This infographic from Solana Daily highlights the top performers on the Solana blockchain over the last 24 hours. The image is divided into three sections: Top Gainers, Most Traded, and Trending. The Top Gainers section displays the tokens with the highest percentage increases, including X4PAY (+41.6%), ACE (+30%), AVO (+29.2%), DREAMS (+28%), and HYPER (+23.9%). The Most Traded section lists tokens with their trading volumes in USD, featuring ACE ($38.25M), DREAMS ($23.99M), SWTCH ($6.89M), PAYAI ($5.21M), and CODEC ($4.04M). The Trending section showcases the tokens currently gaining attention: ACE, PAYAI, X4PAY, SWTCH, and SFY. The Solana Daily logo and social media handles are present at the bottom.

Bitcoin (CBBTC) follows with a price of $91,281 (+1.3%) and a 24-hour volume of $32.08M on Solana. Ethereum (WETH) is priced at $3,136 (+0.8%) with a 24-hour volume of $29.41M. Zcash (ZEC) shows a price of $506.99 (+0.4%) and $10.67M in volume. Monad (MON) and Hyperliquid (HYPE) have volumes of $1.76M and $1.24M respectively. searchParams.query: what are the top trending assets on Solana

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results directly address the query 'top trending assets on Solana' with 15 highly relevant entries. Each result provides lists of tokens, tickers, market data, and trending status specifically within the Solana ecosystem.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The quality is high because the descriptions extract specific data points such as market cap, percentage gains, and price from visual sources. However, as these are image-to-text descriptions, some symbols (e.g., '$?') or very recent meme tokens might have slight formatting issues or lack deep context beyond the snapshot.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The results are very dense with actionable information. Almost every sentence provides a token name, ticker, or metric. There is very little 'filler' text, though there is some redundancy where multiple snapshots of 'Major Assets' (SOL, cbBTC, WETH) are captured across different dates.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search covers a wide spectrum of assets, from 'Majors' (high market cap) to 'Trending' (volatile/new tokens) and even 'DeFi' and 'Equities' (via SpaceX PreStocks). It provides a temporal view spanning several months (Oct 2025 to Jan 2026), which is useful for seeing trends over time, though it doesn't provide a single 'definitive' real-time list.
key_strengths: Diverse sources including Telegram posts, Phantom wallet screenshots, and market dashboards like DexScreener and CoinMun.
Granular data extraction including market caps, 24h volumes, and percentage changes.
Categorization of assets into 'Majors', 'Memecoins', and 'DeFi' allows for a nuanced answer.
key_weaknesses: Temporal fragmentation: The results span from October 2025 to January 2026, making it difficult to determine what is trending 'right now' without checking timestamps.
Some OCR artifacts or placeholder descriptions (e.g., 'token $?' or 'icon, ticker, market cap') occasionally appear in the image descriptions.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search system performed exceptionally well in retrieving specific, data-rich snapshots of the Solana market. It successfully distinguished between high-cap major assets and low-cap trending tokens. While the time range of the results is broad, the density of specific token names and metrics provides a comprehensive foundation for answering the user's query.

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results cover various categories of assets on Solana, including top market cap coins, NFTs, and memecoins. However, many results are landing pages or UI shells rather than active lists of 'trending' assets.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: A significant portion of the provided text consists of website navigation, footers, and legal disclaimers. Several results (CoinScan, Solscan, Messari) contain almost no actual data, only UI labels and placeholders.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The density is low because the system captured a lot of 'noise' tokens (header/footer text). For example, the Solscan and Messari results are almost entirely filler text with no asset names or metrics.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: While it names some specific tokens like SOL, JUP, RENDER, BONK, and PENGU, it lacks a cohesive, real-time 'trending' list. It provides fragments of information across different sectors (DeFi, NFTs, Memecoins) but doesn't synthesize them into a comprehensive answer.
key_strengths: Identifies specific major assets currently relevant to the ecosystem (SOL, JUP, RENDER, BONK).
Provides some variety by including NFT projects like 'Honeyland Generations Bees' and 'Genesis Collection'.
Includes institutional context regarding SOL adoption from AInvest.
key_weaknesses: High volume of scraping noise (navigation menus, 'Sign Up' links, and empty tables).
Several results are dated in the future (late 2025), which may indicate the search system is pulling from predicted/templated content or has timestamp issues.
Lack of 'trending' metrics like 24h volume or social sentiment for many of the mentioned assets.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search results provide a baseline of major Solana assets but fail to deliver a concise list of 'trending' assets due to excessive web-scraping clutter. The user would have to sift through significant amounts of UI text and broken table data to find the few relevant token names. The Kraken result is the most useful, while the Messari and Solscan results are essentially useless in their current snippet form.

rawResponse.title: Twitter's X Rebrand, Assets, & Uncertainty for Marketers
rawResponse.author: Amira Bennerson
rawResponse.text:
Key Points 
 
 
 Elon Musk announced Twitter is becoming an â€œeverything app,â€ but details about changes are scant. 
 Social media platforms are an asset marketers donâ€™t own, exposing brands to risks and volatility from platform or algorithm changes.Â  
 OAO allows strategic elasticity in an ever-changing social media landscape. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 On April 11th, Elon Musk confirmed rumors that Twitter, as such, will no longer exist. Twitter will become an â€œeverything app,â€ rebranding as X. 
 
 Twitter CEO Linda Yaccarino said, â€œX is the future state of unlimited interactivity â€” centered in audio, video, messaging, payments/banking â€” creating a global marketplace for ideas, goods, services, and opportunities.â€Â  
 This sudden change by the enigmatic owner has created a stir in the market.Â  
 Muskâ€™s decision to rebrand Twitter and pivot away from its roots requires us to question the infallibility of major social media networks and how we use them in our marketing strategies. Letâ€™s chew on these questions:Â  
 
 What should we do next?Â  
 How much control do we have over our marketing assets?Â  
 
 Itâ€™s difficult to say what the future of individual social media platforms will be. Ahead of Twitterâ€™s rebranding, Musk made a series of changes to the app. Twitter users were limited to seeing only a few hundred tweets per day. Users reported glitches, site outages, and other UX issues. 
 For many businesses using Twitter, these critical usability issues have inhibited their ability to reach their customers. This, along with other concerns with the platform, led to an advertising exodus, with this springâ€™s ad revenue dropping 59% compared to the previous year. 
 Thereâ€™s an appetite to ditch the chaos to find a safer, more controllable asset. One of the most notable competitors is Metaâ€™s introduction of Threads. However, a few missing Threads features may have contributed to a 50% drop in users within its first week. 
 Mark Zuckerburg is confident in the product despite the drop

# Real-world assets (RWAs)
* A method for turning valuable commodities into digital tokens.
* You can now own portions of real-life objects or assets, rather than having to buy an entire property or item.
* Connects traditional finance with the blockchain ecosystem.
Real-world assets (RWAs) are tokens representing existing forms of wealth, such as real estate, gold, stocks, art, machinery or collectibles. Tokenizing these items translates them into digital form, allowing them to be divided between multiple owners and making it easier to trade them.
## [](#what-are-rwas)What are RWAs?
Some RWAs are tangibleâ€”items you can see and touch, such as gold bars or commercial buildings. Others are intangible, such as government debt, intellectual property, or equity in a company.
When tokenized, these assets are turned into units of value. Tokenized gold is a good example of how this works. The company[Paxosopens in a new tab](https://www.paxos.com/)translates 400-ounce gold bars into 400 tokens on the Ethereum blockchain, each backed by one ounce of gold. Token-holders can redeem their tokens for gold at any point. Thatâ€™s also the case for tokens purchased from another RWA company,[Tether Goldopens in a new tab](https://gold.tether.to/).
Each token can be divided into even smaller fractions. Tether Gold tokens, for instance, can be split into parts as small as 0.000001.
RWA tokens donâ€™t have any intrinsic value. Rather, they reflect the value of the item that the

searchParams.query: what assets are being discussed on twitter

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results capture the keywords 'assets' and 'Twitter' but largely fail to address the core intent of the query, which is identifying trending financial assets (stocks, crypto, etc.) currently being talked about on the platform. Instead, the results focus on Twitter's corporate assets or general definitions of digital assets.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The sources themselves are high-quality (Federal Reserve, White House, Investopedia, CNBC). However, the snippets provided are often heavily cluttered with navigation menus and legal boilerplate, making the actual information hard to extract.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: A significant portion of the search results consists of government website footers, social media links, cookie consent banners, and generic definitions of 'assets'. Only a small fraction of the text attempts to link Twitter and assets, and even then, it is usually in a business-case context rather than a 'trending topics' context.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search results do not provide a list of assets being discussed on Twitter. Result 1 promises 'Most Discussed Topics' but the snippet ends before providing any data. Result 11 discusses Twitter's internal assets (user base) rather than what users are discussing.
key_strengths: Included reputable sources like the Federal Reserve and the U.S. Treasury.
Correctly identified that 'Twitter' is now 'X' in several results.
key_weaknesses: Failed to identify trending financial assets or 'FinTwit' sentiment.
High volume of irrelevant 'noise' from government page footers and navigation menus.
Misinterpreted 'assets' as either corporate property or a regulatory category (RWAs) rather than trending topics.
The most promising result (Result 1) is a truncated snippet with no actual data.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search performance is poor for the specific user intent. The query likely seeks real-time or recent data on which stocks or cryptocurrencies are trending on X (Twitter). The search engine instead returned academic definitions of assets, regulatory reports on digital currencies, and business case studies about Twitter's valuation. While the sources are authoritative, they are not contextually relevant to the specific question of 'what is being discussed'.

# Real-world assets (RWAs)
* A method for turning valuable commodities into digital tokens.
* You can now own portions of real-life objects or assets, rather than having to buy an entire property or item.
* Connects traditional finance with the blockchain ecosystem.
Real-world assets (RWAs) are tokens representing existing forms of wealth, such as real estate, gold, stocks, art, machinery or collectibles. Tokenizing these items translates them into digital form, allowing them to be divided between multiple owners and making it easier to trade them.
## [](#what-are-rwas)What are RWAs?
Some RWAs are tangibleâ€”items you can see and touch, such as gold bars or commercial buildings. Others are intangible, such as government debt, intellectual property, or equity in a company.
When tokenized, these assets are turned into units of value. Tokenized gold is a good example of how this works. The company[Paxosopens in a new tab](https://www.paxos.com/)translates 400-ounce gold bars into 400 tokens on the Ethereum blockchain, each backed by one ounce of gold. Token-holders can redeem their tokens for gold at any point. Thatâ€™s also the case for tokens purchased from another RWA company,[Tether Goldopens in a new tab](https://gold.tether.to/).
Each token can be divided into even smaller fractions. Tether Gold tokens, for instance, can be split into parts as small as 0.000001.

# Real-world assets (RWAs)
* A method for turning valuable commodities into digital tokens.
* You can now own portions of real-life objects or assets, rather than having to buy an entire property or item.
* Connects traditional finance with the blockchain ecosystem.
Real-world assets (RWAs) are tokens representing existing forms of wealth, such as real estate, gold, stocks, art, machinery or collectibles. Tokenizing these items translates them into digital form, allowing them to be divided between multiple owners and making it easier to trade them.
## [](#what-are-rwas)What are RWAs?
Some RWAs are tangibleâ€”items you can see and touch, such as gold bars or commercial buildings. Others are intangible, such as government debt, intellectual property, or equity in a company.
When tokenized, these assets are turned into units of value. Tokenized gold is a good example of how this works. The company[Paxosopens in a new tab](https://www.paxos.com/)translates 400-ounce gold bars into 400 tokens on the Ethereum blockchain, each backed by one ounce of gold. Token-holders can redeem their tokens for gold at any point. Thatâ€™s also the case for tokens purchased from another RWA company,[Tether Goldopens in a new tab](https://gold.tether.to/).
Each token can be divided into even smaller fractions. Tether Gold tokens, for instance, can be split into parts as small as 0.000001.

rawResponse.title: Coinbase Markets on X: Your New Home for All Listings
rawResponse.text:
At Coinbase weâ€™re always looking for ways to make trading easier, faster, and more intuitive for our users. Today, weâ€™re excited to announce a major step in that direction:

**From now on, all new listings across spot, futures, perpetual futures, and more, will be announced from one official channel: the newly rebranded** [**@CoinbaseMarkets**](https://x.com/CoinbaseMarkets) **handle on X.**

## Whatâ€™s Changing?

Until now, asset listings have been announced across multiple Coinbase social handles, often tied to specific platforms like Coinbase Exchange, Coinbase International Exchange, or Coinbase Advanced. This made it harder to track new listings, especially as our product lineup has grown.

Going forward:

One central handle, [**@CoinbaseMarkets**](https://x.com/CoinbaseMarkets), will be the single source of truth for all listing announcements.

Each post will highlight the product type (spot, perps, futures, etc.) and include a thread with details on eligibility, platform access, and how to start trading.

In addition to listings, followers can expect market insights, trends, and trading data.

This change is designed to make your trading experience smoother and more informed, ensuring you know what we are listing, when itâ€™s available, and where it can be traded.

This is more than just a communications change,Â  itâ€™s a foundation for our long-term vision as Coinbase builds an everything exchange. Centralizing our listings announcements ensures that as we grow, you can easily keep track of new opportunities â€” no matter how diverse our product lineup becomes.

## Whatâ€™s Next?

Follow [**@CoinbaseMarkets**](https://x.com/CoinbaseMarkets) **on X** today to stay ahead of every launch. In the coming months, you can expect:

More product variety than ever before.

Deeper market insights and trading data alongside listings.

A more consistent, transparent, and trader-first communication style.

This is just the beginning. With @CoinbaseMarkets as your central listings

searchParams.query: what Base assets are trending on twitter

evaluation.query_relevance_reasoning: The search results are within the correct domain (Crypto/Twitter), but they fail to specifically address 'Base network assets.' Most results focus on general crypto accounts to follow or general market trends rather than identifying specific tokens trending on the Base L2 network.
evaluation.search_contents_quality_reasoning: The sources (CoinGecko, Messari, Santiment) are high-quality and authoritative. However, the snippets provided are mostly landing pages, marketing guides, or generic 'top 10' lists that do not contain the real-time data needed for the query.
evaluation.relevant_information_density_reasoning: The density of relevant information is very low. A large portion of the text is dedicated to social media marketing advice, lists of influencers to follow, and boilerplate website navigation text rather than specific asset names or social volume data for Base tokens.
evaluation.completeness_reasoning: The search fails to provide a list of trending Base assets. Result 10 provides a general trending list (Turtle, Limitless, etc.) which might include Base assets, but it does not specify the network. Result 7 mentions a 'Base Winners' category but the snippet contains no data. The user's specific request is essentially unanswered.
key_strengths: Includes reputable data platforms like CoinGecko, Santiment, and Messari.
Result 7 identifies a tool (Raster) that specifically tracks 'Base Winners,' even if the data didn't populate the snippet.
key_weaknesses: Failed to find a specific list of tokens on the Base network.
Many results are outdated (e.g., a 2022 Medium article) or purely instructional (how to market on Twitter) rather than data-driven.
Heavy reliance on 'best accounts to follow' instead of 'trending assets' content.
evaluation.overall_assessment: The search performance was poor for this specific query. While it correctly identified that the user is looking for a crossover between Twitter trends and Crypto, it failed to filter for the 'Base' network. The results are dominated by generic advice on who to follow on Crypto Twitter rather than providing the requested list of trending assets on the Base blockchain. To improve, the search should have targeted 'Base scan trending' or 'DEXScreener Base trending' alongside Twitter social volume filters.

# Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.

rawResponse.title: Turbine - Solana Handbook
rawResponse.author: Ackee Blockchain Security
rawResponse.text:
Turbine
# Turbine
Turbine is a block propagation protocol designed to reduce both time needed for block propagation as well as the overall message complexity, reducing the communication overhead of a node.
Nodes in the network are divided into small partitions called**neighborhoods**. Nodes within a particular neighborhood are responsible for sharing received data with other nodes in the same neighborhood and propagating the data to a small number of nodes in other neighborhoods.
![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours2.png)![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours.png)
Info
The data unit shared is called a**shred**, and each block is composed of many shreds.
## Problems with Broadcasting
Since we are in an adversarial environment, any node can decide not to rebroadcast the received shreds or broadcast incorrect data.
Countermeasures:
* **Erasure Codes**help by broadcasting a block with more shreds than necessary to reconstruct the entire block without errors, even if some shreds are lost along the way. With 6 data shreds and 3 additional redundant shreds, we can lose up to 1/3 of the shreds and still be able to reconstruct the entire block fully.
* A**stake-weighted selection algorithm**is used to create a tree where the risk of faulty or malicious nodes is minimized. Validators with the highest stake are positioned closer to the current leader.

# Introduction
In traditional blockchains, block propagation occurs through a peer-to-peer network in which new blocks and transactions are broadcast to all propagating nodes. This process usually happens sequentially or is flooded. However, this method is not scalable, as it becomes difficult to manage as the network grows due to the sheer number of communications.
Letâ€™s consider a network of 35,000 validators. The leader needs to transmit a 128 MB block (about 500,000 transactions at 250 bytes per transaction) to all 35,000 validators. The traditional block propagation implementation would require the leader to have a unique connection to each validator and transmit the full 128 MB 35,000 times. This would result in a total data transmission of 4.69 TB, which is far beyond typical bandwidth capabilities and would be infeasible to accommodate with so many connections.
To solve the issue of slow block dissemination, Solana introduced Turbine, a multi-layer block propagation mechanism used by clusters to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. Broadly speaking, Turbine breaks blocks into smaller blocks and disseminates them through an order of nodes, reducing the load on an individual nod

Italo Casas Blog
# Solana Turbine Notes
August 3, 2024
* [https://www.helius.dev/blog/turbine-block-propagation-on-solana](https://www.helius.dev/blog/turbine-block-propagation-on-solana)
* [https://homes.cs.washington.edu/\~tessaro/papers/dds.pdf](https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~tessaro/papers/dds.pdf)
* [https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04371](https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04371)
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reed%E2%80%93Solomon\_error\_correction
* https://docs.anza.xyz/consensus/turbine-block-propagation#layer-assignment----weighted-selection
Turbine is Solana's Block propagation mechanism, allowing all validators to receive the most updated state promptly
Turbine was specifically designed to mitigate the stress of egress from the leader to the network.
At a high level, the turbine breaks blocks into smaller chunks (shreds) and sends those shreds through a hierarchy of nodes.
* Confirmed block: Super majority
* Finalized block: Confirmed and 31+ confirmed block built on top.### [](#shred-propagation)Shred propagation
1. Create block
2. Break block into sub-blocks called shreds via shredding
1. Split data into MTU-size
2. Generates recovery shards via Reed-Solomon
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/641ba798c17bb180d832b666/65383931bb6b0838c0a00577_Shred-level.jpg)
### [](#turbine-tree)Turbine Tree
Structured network topology used by Solana to facilitate the efficient propagation of shards. In other words, it allows for the mitigation of the stress of egress from the leader to the network.
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/641ba798c17bb180d832b666/6538396cabadcf78e8170b03_TurbineTree.jpg)

# Solana’s Turbine: Revolutionizing Blockchain Data Propagation
July 12, 2023 6:14 pm
[BlockChain](https://astconsulting.in/category/blockchain),[Solana](https://astconsulting.in/category/blockchain/solana)
Blockchain technology has rapidly emerged as a disruptive and revolutionary phenomenon in various sectors, providing unparalleled advantages in terms of transparency, security, and decentralized approaches.. However, the scalability and efficiency of blockchain networks have been persistent challenges. Solana, a high-performance blockchain platform, aims to address these challenges with its innovative data propagation solution, Turbine. In this article, we delve into the details of Turbine and explore how it revolutionizes blockchain data propagation.
![Solana's Turbine: Revolutionizing Blockchain Data Propagation](https://astconsulting.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Canva-designs-2023-07-12T154830.496.jpg)## Understanding Blockchain Data Propagation
Blockchain data propagation refers to the process of transmitting data across the network of nodes that validate and maintain the blockchain. In traditional blockchain networks, this process faces several challenges and limitations. Firstly, the speed of data propagation is often slow, leading to network congestion and increased confirmation times. Secondly, as transaction volumes increase, traditional networks struggle to handle the increased load efficiently. These challenges hinder scalability and decentralization, essential aspects of blockchain technology.

A comprehensive, fact-checked guide to how new blocks travel across blockchain networks, why propagation speed matters for security and DeFi, and how leading chains optimize it.

## Introduction
If you have ever asked what is Block Propagation and why it matters, you are already close to understanding a core performance and security factor in every public blockchain. Block propagation is the process by which a newly produced block travels across a peer-to-peer network so that honest nodes converge on the same chain view quickly. The speed, reliability, and consistency of propagation shape user experience, validator incentives, decentralized finance (DeFi) safety, and even the revenue of miners and stakers across networks like[Bitcoin (BTC)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/bitcoin)and[Ethereum (ETH)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/ethereum). It explains both the 'how' and the 'why'.

key_weaknesses: Significant redundancy with duplicate documentation links and near-identical blog posts.

By synthesizing the official docs with the technical handbook results, a user would have a complete understanding of the Turbine protocol. # Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.

# Turbine
Turbine is a block propagation protocol designed to reduce both time needed for block propagation as well as the overall message complexity, reducing the communication overhead of a node.
Nodes in the network are divided into small partitions called**neighborhoods**. Nodes within a particular neighborhood are responsible for sharing received data with other nodes in the same neighborhood and propagating the data to a small number of nodes in other neighborhoods.
![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours2.png)![Blockchain](../../images/neighbours.png)
Info
The data unit shared is called a**shred**, and each block is composed of many shreds.
## Problems with Broadcasting
Since we are in an adversarial environment, any node can decide not to rebroadcast the received shreds or broadcast incorrect data.
Countermeasures:
* **Erasure Codes**help by broadcasting a block with more shreds than necessary to reconstruct the entire block without errors, even if some shreds are lost along the way. With 6 data shreds and 3 additional redundant shreds, we can lose up to 1/3 of the shreds and still be able to reconstruct the entire block fully.
* A**stake-weighted selection algorithm**is used to create a tree where the risk of faulty or malicious nodes is minimized. Validators with the highest stake are positioned closer to the current leader.

# Introduction
In traditional blockchains, block propagation occurs through a peer-to-peer network in which new blocks and transactions are broadcast to all propagating nodes. This process usually happens sequentially or is flooded. However, this method is not scalable, as it becomes difficult to manage as the network grows due to the sheer number of communications.
Letâ€™s consider a network of 35,000 validators. The leader needs to transmit a 128 MB block (about 500,000 transactions at 250 bytes per transaction) to all 35,000 validators. The traditional block propagation implementation would require the leader to have a unique connection to each validator and transmit the full 128 MB 35,000 times. This would result in a total data transmission of 4.69 TB, which is far beyond typical bandwidth capabilities and would be infeasible to accommodate with so many connections.
To solve the issue of slow block dissemination, Solana introduced Turbine, a multi-layer block propagation mechanism used by clusters to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. Broadly speaking, Turbine breaks blocks into smaller blocks and disseminates them through an order of nodes, reducing the load on an individual nod"

# Turbine Block Propagation
A Solana cluster uses a multi-layer block propagation mechanism called*Turbine*to broadcast ledger entries to all nodes. The cluster divides itself into layers
of nodes, and each node in a given layer is responsible for propagating any data
it receives on to a small set of nodes in the next downstream layer. This way
each node only has to communicate with a small number of nodes.
## Layer Structure[â€‹](#layer-structure)
The leader communicates with a special root node. The root can be thought of as
layer 0 and communicates with layer 1, which is made up of at most`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes. If the number of nodes in the cluster is greater than
layer 1, then the data plane fanout mechanism adds layers below. The number of
nodes in each additional layer grows by a factor of`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`.
A good way to think about this is, layer 0 starts with a single node, layer 1
starts with fanout nodes, and layer 2 will have`fanout \* number of nodes in
layer 1`and so on.
### Layer Assignment - Weighted Selection[â€‹](#layer-assignment----weighted-selection)
In order for data plane fanout to work, the entire cluster must agree on how the
cluster is divided into layers. To achieve this, all the recognized validator
nodes(the TVU peers)are shuffled with a stake weighting and stored in a
list. This list is then indexed in different ways to figure out layer boundaries
and retransmit peers - referred to as the(turbine tree). For example, the
list is shuffled and leader selects the first node to be the root node, and the
root node selects the next`DATA\_PLANE\_FANOUT`nodes to make up layer 1. The
shuffle is biased towards higher staked nodes, allowing heavier votes to come
back to the leader first. Layer 2 and lower-layer nodes use the same logic to
find their next layer peers.

Blockchain data propagation refers to the process of transmitting data across the network of nodes that validate and maintain the blockchain. In traditional blockchain networks, this process faces several challenges and limitations. Firstly, the speed of data propagation is often slow, leading to network congestion and increased confirmation times. Secondly, as transaction volumes increase, traditional networks struggle to handle the increased load efficiently. These challenges hinder scalability and decentralization, essential aspects of blockchain technology.

## Introduction
If you have ever asked what is Block Propagation and why it matters, you are already close to understanding a core performance and security factor in every public blockchain. Block propagation is the process by which a newly produced block travels across a peer-to-peer network so that honest nodes converge on the same chain view quickly. The speed, reliability, and consistency of propagation shape user experience, validator incentives, decentralized finance (DeFi) safety, and even the revenue of miners and stakers across networks like[Bitcoin (BTC)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/bitcoin)and[Ethereum (ETH)](https://www.cube.exchange/what-is/ethereum).
